div.p: 1. IV:45. Friday.
Boston. State House Records— Quincy

Morning visit from Mr Peter Whitney— At ten this Morning Dr Warren came out from Boston with his Son, Mason, and performed the operation of taking off the cancer from the breast of Mrs T. B. Adams who bore it with heroic fortitude. Dr Woodward was in attendance as a physician, and my wife and Charles’s were at the house, Mrs Stebbins only being present at the trying scene— The operation was performed in four minutes, and the cancer removed about the size of a walnut— I was engaged to dine with Dr Francis Parkman at Boston, but delayed leaving home till after 11 O’Clock, when I considered it ascertained that no sinister accident had occurred— I then went into Boston in Charles’s Chaise, with a horse from Gillett’s and Thomas to drive me— I drove immediately to the State House and went to Mr Felt’s apartment; and there he brought me the Manuscript Volume of the first Colonial Records beginning in February 1628 in London, before the vote for removing the Charter to New-England— That vote was there; and many others till that of the General Court held on board the Arbella at Charlton after their arrival.— I was there examining this book and making extracts from the records till half past three, during which time Mr Felt went home to dinner and returned. Mr. John P. Bigelow the Secretary of the Commonwealth in the mean time called me in to his Office, and shewed me the original Charter of Charles the 1st. dated in 1828—with the certificate of the official Oath of Matthew Craddock as Governor—which is framed— Also the Charter of William and Mary; and the explanatory Charter of George the first— He gave me also copies of Reports of Commissioners appointed by the Legislature for a Zoological survey of the State—on Quadrupeds by professor Emmons of Williams College—on Birds by Revd. W. O. B. Peabody of Springfield and on Fishes by D. Humphreys Storer M.D of Boston— Also a Report on a re-examination of the economical Geology of Massachusetts by Professor Hitchcock— And with these he sent me bound in two volumes a complete set of the Legislative Documents of the last Session— At half past 3. I went and dined with Dr Francis Parkman, and the Trustees of the Massachusetts humane Society— Of the company I knew Mr P. C. Brooks, Doctor Frothingham, Robert G. Shaw, Henderson Inches, and Revd. G. W. Blagden— The President of the Society B. Rich, Dr. E. H. Robbins, F. J. Oliver, a son of Samuel P Gardiner, and two or three others were strangers. Mrs Parkman was at table— Mr Brooks spoke to me with much regret of Charles’s having declined a nomination for election to the Legislature which has been offered him— I. P. Davis and R. C Winthrop had spoken of it to me yesterday. I came home in the dark reaching my house at half past seven— I made an appointment with R. G. Shaw, to meet him at the Boston Bank, Monday 10. A.M. 11th. of this Month to go and look at the Custom House now being built of Quincy granite— Charles and his wife spent the Evening here
2 III:45 Saturday

Charles went to Boston and returned to dine. Before he went I told him I understood the meeting of the whig Committee at Boston finally to fix upon their list of Representatives for the general Court was held last Evening, and that they had then probably settled their list. But if they had not, I concurred entirely with Mr Brooks in the wish that he would withdraw his refusal to stand as a Candidate; in which he acquiesced— After two days of dissipation, I found it impossible this day to return to that assiduity of application indispensable to go through my present daily task, of writing three pages for my Lecture; the diary of the day and to retrieve the arrears of two successive days at Boston— A man by the name of Levi Stearns who said he came from the town of Sweden, I suppose in the State of Maine, where he had lost his house and property by fire—he asked for a gift of cast off garments and had a bundle of them under his arm— He said also that he belonged to the Methodist Church— I had no reason to mistrust his statement, which had every appearance of sincerity— Miss Cutts returned here this afternoon from her visit to Miss Elizabeth Crowninshield. Dr. Mifflin the husband of Elizabeth Crowninshield brought her home— I was at Charles’s about half an hour at the twilight after Sunset— I finished this day a Lecture on the Smithsonian bequest, but finding that I have not said half of what it was my intention to include in one discourse I began upon a second, which if ever finished I have no doubt will be as long as the first.— I had no space in the diary of the 31st. of last month to give my usual summary of daily occupations during the month, and may as well give it now— My rising hour as usual between 4 and 5— I make my fire wash and dress which takes me a full hour— Often more— Then read or write till 8. Breakfast—read Letters and Newspapers or pamphlets brought by the mail till 2 P.M with intervals of writing; about 2 hours— After dinner half an hour or an hour of idleness for digestion—then an equal time till Sunset, now before 5 again writing. From that time till 10. P.M. with an interval of half an hour for tea, and a cup of hot cocoa-shells for me I spend with my family— Charles and his wife come in for an hour between 7 and 8. Ten is our bed time— On the 5th. of October I began writing the Lectures which I had promised to deliver this Season— On the 24th. I delivered the one at Braintree which became an address to the Inhabitants of the Town— I have now prepared one for the Quincy Lyceum, and for the Boston Mechanic Apprentice’s Library Association, and this day begin upon a second, which will consume all the remainder of my time, till my necessary if practicable departure for Washington. This is but a form of wasting time; but I passed it with as much comfort as a man in the 73d. year of his age can enjoy till Louisa C. Smith and afterwards the child Fanny were taken sick— My Cousin is slowly convalescent from a lingering disease; but that of the child is one of deep and sharpening distress, to her mother, her grandmother and me— It embitters every moment of my life, and urges me to prepare for an event which I can neither look in the face nor avert.
3. V. Sunday.

The child Fanny had a bad night and her mother is in deep anguish. Dr Holbrook was here this Morning and spoke to me in doubtful and ambiguous terms of her condition. I can but bow with resignation to the Will of Heaven, and pray that if possible this cup may pass from me— It was a chilly—dull—gloomy day. Mr Lunt preached this morning, from 2. Corinthians 7.1. perfecting holiness in the fear of God. The argument of the discourse was that all virtue is founded upon religion; that there can be no perfect holiness, or righteousness but by the fear of God— This I believe to be true— For independent of the conviction of responsibility hereafter to a just and merciful God, all moral principle resolves itself into selfishness and expediency— For then comes the utilitarian doctrine which is all selfishness, every man’s passions and prejudices persuading him that his own good is always the greatest good of the greatest number— Mr Lunt dwells so much and so often upon this principle that all righteousness is founded on religion, that it gives a monotonous character to his Sermons— It was yet more evinced by his discourse this afternoon from Luke 17.21. “for behold the kingdom of God is within you.[”] On the 9th. of September 1838. he preached both parts of the day on this text, and my approbation of the first part of the discourse was then recorded, with a pause for the sermon of the afternoon. That was what he now repeated, and it did not gain in my estimate by repetition— The spiritual kingdom of Christ is undoubtedly a fundamental tenet of Christianity, but when it has been clearly and explicitly laid down, though it may be often illustrated and commented upon, it should be more frequently be seasoned with variety of discourse upon practical morals—upon scriptural narratives and characters—upon the poetical effusions of David— Upon the Loves, the worldly wisdom and the melancholy disappointments of Solomon— Upon the mysterious revelations of the prophets—the biographical Memoirs of the Evangelists, and upon the Acts and Epistles of the Apostles— All these furnish abundant materials for variety without losing sight of the essentially spiritual nature of the Christian Religion. I read the 50th. of Barrow’s Sermons, being the first of the five upon Industry— My father considered these as some of the best discourses that were ever preached or published— They teem with thought as if they were poured out from an inexhaustible fountain— The style is plain and dry; so different from that of Lord Chatham’s speeches that I can hardly credit what I have heard that Chatham studied it as a model. He frequently quotes the Greek and Latin Classicks, and the Fathers, above all St. Chrysostom— The first and second of the five Sermons are upon Industry in general—the third upon our Industry as Christians—the fourth upon our Industry as Gentlemen, and the fifth upon our Industry as Scholars— Charles and his wife were here this Evening.
4. IV:30. Monday

The weather has grown colder, and the sky clearer. This was a fine and almost cloudless day, but chilling cold— Charles went to Boston and returned to dine. My wife took an early dinner and went with Miss Cutts to Boston and returned to tea— Charles’s wife was to have gone, but stayed to amuse the child, who is very dangerously ill— Deacon Spear was here, and brought a plan of the woodlot, at the foot of Penn’s hill, upon which I have concluded to sell the standing wood.— It is laid out intolots for sale. The Deacon takes no responsibility in recommending the choice of an auctioneer; but he says that Harvey Field, who has always been employed for this service heretofore, did not perform the service well last year— That he is now subject to frequent convulsion fits which disable him from the vigorous performance of so laborious a duty— That his credit is running low, and he is deeply involved in debt, and greatly embarrassed with a multitude of doubtful speculations. That his reputation for integrity is not altogether unsullied, and for punctuality wholly gone—and he warmly recommended Major Thomas Adams junr as a first rate auctioneer— I told the Deacon, that I was exceedingly unwilling to discard a man who was in falling fortune; but that of course I must take a man of unsuspected integrity and of undoubted integrity— He might therefore employ Major Adams. Peter Turner was here and took my measure for two pair of shoes— This is another middle aged man, who was once a very promising young man, and a master workman at his trade— But he plunged into speculations upon lands and roads, and is now swamped in irredeemable debt—and neglects his trade so that he has not yet made me two pair of shoes which I ordered weeks ago— I dined with Charles, and in returning home, found Dr Holbrook here— I asked him to say to me candidly what he thought of the poor child’s case— He said as I had asked the question he must tell me it was a case not without danger.— He could not speak with certainty, and perhaps not yet for eight or ten days—but there was danger— I have long been afflicted with an apprehension that this poor child was destined to short life. There is so much of the angel in her already that she seems all fitted for a better world— I have watched the symptoms of her disease with a trembling heart and with sinking hope, and am sure that the Doctor has none— His postponement of a decisive opinion is only to prepare us for it when it will come.— The trial to myself is excruciating— To the mother, and to my dear wife it is inexpressible. May the consolations of a meek and quiet spirit, and of a hope beyond the grave be extended to them and to me— Mr and Mrs Lunt, and Charles and his wife were here this evening.
5. IV:20. Tuesday
Sun rose 6:38. Set 4:50.— Day 10 hours 42 minutes.
Fahrenheit at Sunrise 20.

I saw the Sun rise from the corner of Charles’ house rapidly approaching to the rear of the Steeple of the Stone meeting house— As I came down the hill I first heard the cackling, and then heard saw the flight from North-east to Southwest of a large flock of wild geese—intelligent of Seasons— The sky was clear— The day bitter cold; so that with a large and constant fire in my chamber, I could not keep myself steady at my writing table; and my hand shook and my body shivered so that I could not keep the command of my pen, and repeatedly blotted my paper as will be seen by turning back this leaf— My darling child too has suffered much this day— I saw her in one of her paroxysms of pain, which would have melted the heart of a Savage— It put mine upon the rack—aggravated by the consciousness that the case is remediless, and the agonizing anticipation of how much she has yet to suffer. My wife too in addition to her keen distress was this day tortured with the tooth ache, and neither she nor Mary will pass through this trial without severe and alarming illness of their own— I have no heart to read or write; and yet time flies and the record must not flag so long as I can hold the pen— I have found it impossible as yet to recover the whole of my Diary arrears but have nearly accomplished it— I received a Letter from Mr George L. Curry President of the Mechanic Apprentice’s Library Association, enquiring what will be the subject of my Lecture before them— I answered him and gave him notice that I must either have two Evenings for lecturing or can discourse to them only half my subject— I received also a Letter from Samuel Shock of Columbia Pennsylvania, stating that he will propose himself as a Candidate for the Office of Clerk of the House of Representatives of the United States at the approaching meeting of Congress, with a recommendatory certificate from 44 Anti-Van Buren members of the late Convention for amending the Constitution of the State of Pennsylvania— Also a Letter from J. M. Van Cott, George C. Dixon—A. J. Spooner and R. Cochran, lecturing Committee of the Hamilton literary Association of Brooklyn, Long Island dated 28. Octr. 1839. requesting me to deliver a Lecture before them on my way to Washington through New-York— And in support of this application a Letter from Revd. Dr Samuel H. Cox—urging me to comply with the invitation— The Doctor’s Letter is full of enthusiastic attachment and fulsome flattery— J’ai lhonneur d’etre, tout ce quon met au bas d’une Lettre—but what seems specially and last to have delighted him, was the words “atoning lamb,” in my hymn of the Hour glass lately published. Charles spent the latter part of the Evening here—and his wife the whole Evening.— They are to remove to-morrow into Boston for the winter—
6. IV:20. Wednesday.

Charles with his wife and family removed this day in to Boston for the Winter— They took Mary-Louisa with them— She has been several days at their house in consequence of the illness of her sister Fanny. Dr Holbrook this day, thought her better and gaves encouragement for hope which I dare not indulge, but cannot resist— I saw too plainly that there was no real improvement— I hurried on with my writing the whole day long—redeemed at last the immediate arrears of this diary, and found I had omitted noting on the 10th. of last Month the account of the new suspension of specie payment by the Philadelphia Banks, and the resumption of my Chronometer at Mr Bond’s on the 12th— I forgot also to mention that last Evening, Mr Edward Miller’s daughter Hannah was married to Mr George Tyler Bigelow at Boston— A person by the name of Nelson Moore came this afternoon deputed from a literary Society at Waltham, calling themselves the Adams and Rumford association, to request me to deliver a Lecture or Address before them— I could not answer positively— I objected both the state of my health, and the condition of my family; but his solicitations were so earnest and importunate, that I told him, that if he should not hear from me before next Saturday week he might call for me here in a chaise at four O’Clock in the afternoon, and I would go and deliver a Lecture at Waltham, and should wish to be home here the next morning by ten O’Clock in time for the morning service at Meeting; all, which he very readily promised, and I told him that if any thing in the meantime should occur to prevent my coming I will give him notice of it by the mail— I shall try my first Lecture on the Smithsonian bequest here next Wednesday and at Boston the next day— The second will I trust then be finished— If I fail here or at Boston, I will retrench my visit to Waltham. If I succeed but tolerably, I will compress the two Lectures into one, and deliver it at Waltham, and perhaps at Brooklyn— If I can possibly rouse the public mind to take some interest in this foundation, it may save the fund from being utterly wasted and lost; and the more frequently I go before the public upon it, the more chances will there be for connecting public sympathies with it— The experiment is desperate; but with a blessing it may succeed— Mr French the Schoolmaster, came to invite me from the School Committee, to attend the examination of his school at 9. O’Clock next Friday Morning— At 7. O’Clock P.M. I walked, pitch dark to the Town Hall where I found Mr Cornell delivering a Lecture upon Education— Much of which I had delivered last week at Braintree though he knew nothing of it— His Lecture was short; and after he concluded two questions which had lain over for discussion were successively taken up— The first whether the contemplated centennial celebration would be a benefit to the rising generation? This question had been raised by George Newcomb in consequence of the opposition against the measure which had unexpectedly appeared in Town meeting— But he alone spoke in favour of the celebration. No one spoke against it and the question when taken, had not a single negative voice. The vote against the violation of the license law— Thomas came up for me with a lantern and an umbrella, and escorted me home.
7. III:50. Thursday
Sun rose 6:40. Set 4:48. Day 10 hours 8 minutes.
Fahrenheit 34 at Sunrise.

Saw the Sun rise from the S.E. corner of Charles’s house and as I rose just before 4. O’Clock, when I entered my writing chamber the first object that met my eye fronting my N.E. window was Arcturus, and near beside him was the Northern crown; while about forty degrees South of him was Venus about as much risen shining with great brilliancy. I saw the Sun rise from behind the chimney of a dwelling house, and infer that he will rise behind the steeple of the Stone Meeting house about the 1st. of December.— Dr. Holbrook was here this afternoon, and thinks Fanny better, but I see no evidence of it that makes any impression upon my belief.— Louisa C. Smith is also still confined to her chamber. I gave John Kirke this day all the peach and plum stones, shagbark walnuts and English white Oak-Acorns that I have gathered these two Months and he planted them in the cross border at the North end of my Orchard upon that border also he has set out all the seedlings uprooted from the garden, Nursery and Seminary— After the setting in of the month of October, I have always found my taste for planting nearly extinguished this year it has turned to distaste and aversion.— I can live to see no results from any planting of mine after this date, and there is not a single member of my family who takes any interest in my plantations— At this moment I have no leisure to devote to them if I would, for the Smithsonian Lectures and the Diary absolutely grind me down. I walked this afternoon to Mrs T. B. Adams’s, and saw her in her chamber. She looks pale and somewhat emaciated; but is recovering from the extrication of the cancer uncommonly well. Her Sister Mrs Stebbins is with her— Elizabeth her daughter had not returned home when I was there, but came within half an hour after, from Boston in the Stage— She brought a note from Charles’s wife to mine— Elizabeth comes home sick with a very severe cough and sore throat— She was engaged to be present at the wedding of Miss Hannah, who prefers the name of Anna Miller— The situation of her mother was concealed from her and she was sent off to Medford on the day of the operation, that she might not be disappointed of the pleasure of being at the wedding— This took place on Tuesday evening and Elizabeth was there still ignorant of her mother’s situation— This was made known to her only this day and she hastened home from the house of feasting to a sick chamber and a sick bed— She has been saved however from much distress of mind, and finds her mother much better than she could have anticipated.
8. IV:15. Friday.
Sun rose 6:42. Set 4:47. Day 10 hours 5. minutes

Saw the Sun rise again from the S.E corner of Charles’s house— Though excessively pressed for time I attended the examination of the central town School kept by Mr Jonathan French and MissThey commenced at 9 O’Clock, but I was not there before half past ten— There are now there about 90 scholars male and female in about equal proportions— Their reading writing, (I did not witness the examination in cyphering) parsing, composition, drawing and Geography are all improved since the last year. Many of the Scholars appear to take a warm taste for drawing, especially in water colours.—but Mr French says all the drawing is done out of School hours. I have some doubts of the usefulness of their mapping; and think some part of the time they bestow upon that might be more profitably employed in forming a fair handwriting— They have no copper plate copies and the teachers own hand is not exemplary— The examination however taken altogether was creditable, the children orderly and well dressed.— Mr Lunt, Mr Wolcott the Episcopal Clergyman, Captain John Whitney, Mr Marsh, Mr James Newcomb and Mr John Briesler were there; but when the Bell for Noon rang and the school was to be dismissed they asked me to address the children— There was a short composition of one of the girls under the head of School, urging the duty of diligent attendance to it in all weathers, and remarking that composition was useful though lazy Scholars thought it hard— I read the whole of this composition, commented upon it briefly and commended it, believing that it would afford gratification to the child herself and prove a stimulant to emulation to the whole School. I had barely reached home, when Mr Henry Bowditch, a younger son of the late Dr Bowditch came with an invitation to me to deliver a Lecture to an Association at the Warren Street Chapel in Boston— I told him that I had engaged to deliver a Lecture to the Mechanic Apprentice’s Library Association; and found that I could not comprize the Subject in less than two— As this might not be convenient to them, I had left it at their option, to give me a second evening for the second Lecture or to postpone it to another Season— If they should postpone, I could then deliver the second Lecture at the Warren street chapel— Mr Bowditch said he would see Mr Curry the President of the Mechanic Apprentice’s Library Association and endeavour to make an arrangement with him— Mr Michael Burns an itinerant book pedlar here came with Sparks’s life of Washington, and Yates’s secret debates in the federal Convention of 1787. both which books I had— Charles and his wife came and dined with us— He returned to Boston after dinner leaving her here— A Mr Bussell from Alton New Hampshire came with his nephew Mr Flanders of this place Mrs Stebbins was also here.
9. V. Saturday.
Boston— Probate Office— Quincy to dine

I went into Boston this morning in the carriage to meet Mr George Fuller the Administrator on the Estates of Governor Gill, and of the late Moses Gill, and Mr Nathaniel Curtis at the probate Office. On calling at the Office I found they had been there and left word they would soon come again— I called at Charles’s Office, where he and Mr Spooner were— Mr Curtis soon after came in, and went with me to the probate office, where the Judge, and then Mr Fuller appeared— The judge took up my account, added to it an allowance of 600 dollars for the charges of the administration and a reservation of 984:78 cents for the note from the late Moses Gill to Mrs Boylston, and then took my Oath to the account, and also that I had given notice in the Boston Courier three weeks successively of the presenting the account as he had ordered— The day mentioned in the notice was of next Monday the 11th. but the judge told me there would be no need for me to come again then as his order would be dated as of that day— But Mr Fuller as Administrator of the late Moses Gill, could agree to nothing. He shewed me a Letter from a person named Prentiss enquiring if he intended to represent the Estate as insolvent, and averring that he and several other persons had been called upon to pay 11000, which with the interest would amount to 22,000 as sureties on the Bonds of Mr Gill.— But there was no pretence that they had paid a single dollar, and I had with me a deed of Covenants between Ward N. Boylston and Moses Gill, wherein reciting the judgment obtained by Boylston against Gill of 108000 dollars in the Supreme Court of the State, Boylston covenants in consideration of Gill’s giving up the Estates of T. Boylston then in his possession, not to levy execution upon the sureties to his bonds—and accordingly it never was levied on the sureties— Mr Fuller asked the loan of this paper, promising to return it after having a copy of it made. I left it with him— The annuity Bond of W. N. Boylston to Moses Gill, which Mr Fuller had written to me to ask to see, Mr Curtis said was in his possession, and he promised to shew it to him— As Mr Fuller could come to no compromise about the note to Mrs Boylston, I said I should reserve the Bank shares and await the issue of a suit from Mr Fuller—but said I supposed the judge of Probate for the County of Worcester might authorise a compromise if Mr Fuller thought proper— He asked me for a statement of facts to present to the judge of probate in Worcester County—which I promised to make out and send him— It was half past One O’Clock I went immediately to Charles’s house, where Thomas was in waiting for me with the Carriage— I took up Miss Cutts, and we came home to dine— Dr Holbrook was here after dinner— The dear child Fanny has been extremely ill the whole day— Her mother and Grand mother are both in the deepest distress—
4. IV:15 Sunday

Mr Young Minister of the New South Church at Boston preached this morning from Luke 9.28. “And it came to pass, about an eight days after these sayings, he took Peter and John, and James, and went up in to a mountain to pray. 29. And as he prayed, the fashion of his countenance was altered, and his raiment was white and glistening. 30 And behold there talked with him two men, which were Moses and Elias 31 Who appeared in glory, and spake of his decease which he should accomplish at Jerusalem.”— The transfiguration—the third Sermon that I have heard upon this subject within the present year— There is a mysterious and awful solemnity about that transaction which makes it very difficult to treat successfully. The picture of Raphael represents Jesus, Moses and Elias as suspended in the air above the hill, for which there is no authority in the text, and which always disgusts me in the picture itself.— Mr Young considers Moses as the representative of the old covenant, and Elias as the representative of all the prophets of that dispensation; and he dwelt largely upon the cloud from which issued the voice— This is my beloved Son— Hear him— It seems to have been a preternatural scene, the object of which was to communicate to the Apostles by indirect intimation not then understood by themselves the superseding from that time of the Law from Sinai, before the light of the gospel. Mr Young dined with us, and his afternoon text was from Romans 12.2. “And be not conformed to this world; but be ye transformed by the renewing of your mind, that ye may prove, what is that good and acceptable and perfect will of God”— This was something of a political discourse; and in the exhortations not to be conformed to this world, the preacher inveighed against the extravagant manners of the times, which are indeed very great— He referred to the disordered state of the currency and the delinquency of the banks, but told the people that their own profusion and wastefulness was the cause of their disasters—and so no doubt it is— Prosperity has relaxed the morals of the People— There is no lack of Industry— But there are no poor,—except the infirm and the maimed— Wages are enormously high, and there are no menial servants but foreigners— Mr Young has attended much to the early history of the Plymouth and Massachusetts Colonies, and mentioned to me several antient documents with which I was not acquainted— Mr De Grand came out also from Boston and dined with us; but Fanny who is sinking into the grave was so extremely ill, that Dr Holbrook desired that a consulting physician are should be called in, and Mr Degrand took in a note from my wife to Charles requesting Charles to engage Dr Bigelow to come and meet Dr Holbrook here to-morrow.— We are in a state of great distress and wretchedness— I was my self afflicted this day with hoarseness and a sore throat, and found it impossible to pursue my reading and writing with composure— I finished reading the second and read the third of Barrow on Industry—as Christians, but to little profit from involuntary inattention.
11. IV. Monday

My wife spent the night with Fanny, whose case presents no symptom upon which a rational hope can be built and whose gradual decline is among the severest trials with which it has pleased divine Providence to visit me upon earth— My hoarseness and sore throat roused me from sleep about 2 this morning— After lying restless and disturbed till four I rose and applied myself to the labours of the day.— I wrote to John G. Whittier to enclose a printed copy of his ode on the grave of Morgan, with a misprinted line which I wish him to rectify; and a revised copy of my Sonnet to the Morning Star, which I saw this morning, according to the American Almanac in her greatest brilliancy— Mr William Rice of Weymouth, and Captain John Hardwick were here about a contract for the erection of a beacon monument in the Boston, which Rice undertook, and in which Hardwick was interested— It proved that the work was much heavier and more costly than had been anticipated at the making of the contract; but Rice completed it, under encouragement from the Collector Bancroft, of supplementary compensation— But now he refers Rice, first to the fifth auditor of the Treasury to whom he has written and from whom he has no answer, and next to Congress, by Petition. The case seems to be precisely that of Ebenezer Lobdell. I advised Mr Rice to press the Collector to get a favourable decision from the fifth Auditor, or the Secretary of the Treasury. And also to be prepared with a petition to Congress and a certificate from the Collector, to give or send to me to be presented to the House of Representatives at the very commencement of the Session— I told him how impossible it was to get a private claim through Congress unless presented very early in the Session, and he promised to follow my advice— Charles and his wife came out from Boston and dined with us— He returned to Boston after dinner and left her here. Dr Holbrook and Doctor Bigelow met here at noon and held a consultation upon the case of our dear little suffering child— They gave us no hope of her recovery— She has been to me an angel upon earth, and the only consolation that the Mercy of Heaven can bestow for the loss of her will be, that she may be taken away from the evil to come— I cannot survive her long, and may humbly hope to rejoin her in the world of Spirits where there is neither sorrow nor mourning, and where every tear shall be wiped from every eye— This was the day of the annual election of Governor, Lieutenant Governor, Senators and Representatives in the Legislature of the State. I went to the Town Hall, and deposited my vote for Governor, Lieutenant Governor and Senators— The Hall was crowded to suffocation; and just as I pressed my way into it Dr Duggan the chairman of the Selectmen announced that the poll was opened, and the votes would be taken alphabetically by letters— A was first called and my vote was one of the first deposited in the box— The town vote was 326 for Morton, and 231. for E. Everett for Governor. The vote for Representaves was postponed.
12. IV. Tuesday
Sun rose 6:47. Set 4:42. Day 9 hours 55 minutes.
Fahrenheit at Sun-rise 22.
I saw the Sun rise from the S.E. corner of Charles’s House—he is now drawing close to the Stone temple.

Mrs Charles F. Adams returned to Boston before dinner— Miss Cutts went with her—dined in Boston and came home this evening. Jotham Lincoln of Hingham called here on his way to Boston, and told me of the vote in the town of Hingham which was strong in favour of the re-election of Edward Everett as Governor; but he said he feared he had lost his election; which is exceedingly probable— But he said that the whig Senators for the County of Plymouth were elected which I do not believe. The cause of this political revolution in the politics of the State, is the 15 gallon license law of April 1838 a temperance blue law, enacted with the best intentions for the preservation and reformation of the morals of the People, but intrenching too much upon individual liberty— Mr Lunt was here also before dinner and returned one of the volumes which he had borrowed of me. He asked me leave to retain some time longer Savage’s Edition of Winthrop’s journal—to which I readily agreed. He said his Sermons would not be published within a month from this time— Dr Holbrook was here this afternoon— The only material change of treatment after the consultation with Dr. Bigelow was the administration of the warm bath which has produced no mitigation of the disease, though perhaps a momentary softening of the symptoms— My own hoarseness and sore throat have partly given way to a cold in the head and feverish heat— Yet my engagements press upon me— I finished this day, my second Lecture upon the Smithsonian bequest— But they have been written under the harrow of such distress of mind, that they are unfit to go before the public, and I fear will be found insupportably tedious and dull— I have done scarcely any thing that I intended— I have not set forth at large the reasons for objecting to the application of any portion of the funds to purposes or institutes of education— I have not set forth at large the reasons for devoting the appropriations for a series of years to an astronomical observatory. These are points upon which it will be important to dwell with power in the argument to be maintained before Congress, the preparation of which will be much mored laborious and difficult than that of these Lectures. The arguments against application of the funds to education are the multitudes of such institutions already existing, and the impossibility of equalising its benefits to all the people of the Union—State and Sectional jealousies, and no prospect of any evident and palpable increase of knowledge— The arguments in favour of an Observatory, the history of that of Greenwich, and superadded facts—France—Russia—Naples— The representatives for the town of Quincy, to the legislature of the State for the year 1840. chosen this day are Nathaniel White, Alexander Bent and George Baxter—all democrats.
13. IV. Wednesday

Captain George Drew of Halifax in the County of Plymouth brought me a Letter from Obadiah Lyon Esqr. a magistrate of that town that the whigs there have had several meetings preparatory to the late election, and have at last formed themselves into whig reading society to meet weekly during the winter for the purpose of political information. That they appointed him a committee to procure a whig paper from Washington during the winter, and he encloses a two dollar bill with a request that I would procure and forward to him the best Washington paper that may be had for the money— I told Mr Drew I should send the tri-weekly National Intelligencer for the payment of which perhaps something more than the two dollars would be required— Halifax is one of the Towns disaffected to the Administration of the State and this throws them at once into the arms of the federal administration— The fifteen gallon Law intrenches upon personal liberty—the repeal of the bounty of 5 dollars a day to the volunteer company militia men, touches the purse—and these two ill-judged measures have revolutionized the State— The custom house and the Post-Office are used by Van Buren’s Officers as electioneering engines with brazen-faced and shameless publicity— Bancroft appoints inspectors in every town upon the coast, and wherever a Postmater not devoted to Van Buren and Amos Kendall, they turn him out and supply a devoted tool in his place. The whigs have suffered this process to be going on without remonstrance, and almost without notice, and they are now suffering the consequences.— Dr Holbrook was here this afternoon— It is to me excruciating agony to see the child, and yet impossible not to hang by the Spider’s thread of hope— It seems to me that she cannot remain many days longer, and yet the doctors yet speak of a lingering disease and possible recovery— Prepare us oh God for our trials, and for resignation to thy will— At 7. O’Clock this Evening I walked to the Town Hall, and though labouring under great hoarseness, and a hacking cough delivered the first of my two lectures on the Smithsonian bequest, which took me one hour and twenty minutes— The hall was crowded to its utmost capacity—with two or three women to one man— The attention of the auditory was well sustained, though parts of the discourse were evidently tiresome— A resolution of thanks was adopted with a request to me to deliver the second Lecture this day week, and the Lyceum was adjourned to next Wednesday Evening, at half past six O’Clock— I rode home, shortly before the Evening bell, and retired to bed with a cup of spearmint tea.
14. IV:20 Thursday.

Mr Luther Rogers of Marshfield came this morning with his brother Clift Rogers an inhabitant of Quincy with a copy of certain proceedings of delegates from the towns of Scituate, Marshfield, Hanover Hanson and Pembroke, last February, petitioning Congress for a new survey of the North river with a view to removing obstructions and opening a canal for the improvement of the Navigation— They sent their petition to Daniel Webster to be presented to the Senate, and sent none to the House—perhaps because it was in substance a Counter petition to the one that I had presented from Scituate, which was before the Committee of Commerce of the House. Nothing was done at the last Session with either and it is apparent that if the two petitions are brought into conflict with each other at the approaching Session; nothing will then be done— Mr Luther Rogers junr left with me a copy of the proceedings of the delegates from the four towns last February; and two maps, one of Scituate of the same impression with that given me by S. A. Turner, and one of Marshfield, Scituate and the adjoining towns, which Mr Rogers said was more accurate— He said they had heard of my visit to Scituate, and viewing that harbour, and the adjoining beach and course of the North river, and they would be glad if I could again go, and view the position of Marshfield. I expressed my regret that this would be impossible before the approaching Session for which it would be necessary for me to take my departure the week after next and he said they had forborne to send me an invitation, under the expectation that I should not be able to come— I said if they proposed to petition again they would do well to forward two copies of it, one to the Senate and the other to the House of Representatives— Dr Holbrook came this day before dinner, and the child is yet declining daily and hourly— The last event cannot be remote, and the thought of it is excruciating agony.— I finished this day the supplementary address to the members of the Mechanic Apprentices Library Association additional to the second Lecture on the Smithsonian Institution— And at four O’Clock this afternoon I came into Boston, to My Son’s House— At 7. in the evening I went with him to the Masonic Temple, where I found in attendance George L Curry President of the Mechanic Apprentices Library Association with two other Apprentices, named Drew andAt half past seven I commenced the delivery of the Lecture and finished at 40 minutes past 8.— The house was hardly filled—the auditory consisted chiefly of the apprentices and their relatives— William Foster and William Sturgis were almost the only persons whom I knew in the Hall— A Doctor Jackson who has made a geological survey of the State of Maine was introduced to me and enquired if among the plans for employing the Smithsonian funds Lectures on Agriculture had been thought of. We came home before 9 to Charles’s house, where I am to pass the Night.
15. IV:45. Friday.
Return to Quincy.

I rose before 5. and in Charles’s study wrote my Journal of yesterday before breakfast. I wrote also a Letter to Nelson Moore at Waltham, to notify him that I cannot come there to-morrow evening to deliver a Lecture, as I had conditionally promised— The speaking of the last two Evenings has aggravated my Catarrhal fluxion which is returning upon me: but my decisive motive was that the condition of my family to morrow evening will be such as probably to forbid my leaving home for the Night— After breakfast I read cursorily Adam Smith’s fragment of a summary history of Astronomy, with that feeling so strong in reading a good book, and so seldom realized, that I must return to it again— I had read this before— It is a rapid sketch of astronomical theories, from Pythagoras and Thales to Newton tracing them all to wonder, surprize and admiration; which he defines and discriminates.— There is another source of astronomical and all other theories more powerful than these—Curiosity—the thirst for knowledge— The thread of the labyrinth from effect to cause— Dr Smith says that the great majority of mankind, never throughout their whole lives take any notice of the movements of the stars at all— Then they can scarcely move either wonder, surprize or admiration—but as the eye cannot look to Heaven without seeing them, the moment the human being exercises the faculty of thought upon what he sees—the what and the wherefore, the why and the when rush to his mind and he theorises. I cannot now pursue this train of thought copious as it is— I called at Mrs S. A. Otis’s and saw Osgood’s copy of my father’s Portrait last painted by Stuart, and made for Mr Downing of Newburg New-York, the husband of Caroline De Wint— It is neither a very bad, nor a good copy— Miss Welsh was not at home and Mrs Otis was engaged. I met Miss Welsh in the Street; disappointed not to have known that I lectured last Evening—but I gave her a ticket for the course. I went to the common council-room at the City Hall, and was two hours making extracts from the old book of records relating to mount Wollaston—down to the 27th. of January 1639. they were not altogether satisfactory— The grants of lands to individuals are very numerous—and as early as 3. December 1636. there was a Committee of the Governor and 7 others to see to the ripening of the business of a Town and Church at the Mount— On my return to Charles’s house, Mrs George Parkman and her daughter came in on a visit, but being veiled, I did not recognize them— Mr William Lawrence came to enquire at the instance of Mr Saltonstall if I thought it expedient for the claimants on Hayti to memorialize Congress for the recognition I said yes,—though it might be unavailing. Dr George Parkman came in after dinner— And Charles’s wife came out with me to Quincy.
16. V. Saturday.

Our lovely suffering child after a restless night and under the influence of Strymonium from about 6 this morning became speechless and continued so the whole day— In the alarm occasioned by this incident Dr Woodward was sent for, and thought it the effect of the Medicine and would pass off in the 24 hours. Dr Holbrook was also sent for, and at our dinnertime the two physicians held a consultation, but there was no relief to the child— My Son came out from Boston, dined with us, and with his wife returned home after dinner. She had passed the night watching with Fanny. I wrote a note to the lecture Committee of the Hamilton literary Society at Brooklyn, Long Island, declining their invitation to deliver a Lecture before them— And I answered a Letter from Brigadier General Fisher A. Kingsbury of Weymouth, about two petitions from Weymouth Braintree and Quincy, to Congress for an appropriation for removing obstructions to the navigation of Weymouth fore-river— I presented these petitions to the House on the 18th. of last February—they were referred to the Committee of Commerce, and there slept— Kingsbury is a demagogue lawyer, and the mud of Weymouth fore river is part of his political stock in trade; together with Anti-Masonry, Abolition, the Militia, and the Post-Office and last and most of all Democracy— In all this his first care is for himself, I never to my knowledge saw the man, but he has been very officious in correspondence with me about the Post-Office and abolition.— But last winter he sent some abolition Petitions to Caleb Cushing, telling him that my abolition constituents had lost their confidence in me— This bustling busy body’s democracy has made him already a Brigadier General, and with all his abolitionism Amos Kendall has just given him the Post Office at Weymouth— It is a curious symptomatic fact, how many of these raving abolitionists, abuse and vilify me in public and consult me, and court my opinions in private correspondence. Darling virtues like favourite children breed injustice to the rest of the family. Mr Robert Capen a physician formerly of Plymouth now of Hingham, called and told me that he was writing upon natural history and upon diseases— That he wanted to procure Cuvier’s works upon natural history and Farmer on Demoniacs and on Miracles— That he had thought they might be in my library, and if so would be glad to borrow them.— I told him that I owned neither of those books myself; but I lent him Farmer’s works in four Volumes from the Adams library taking his receipt and a promise to return them in good condition within 90 days. I wrote the name of the Library also in the books. Peter Turner came to tell me, that he could not pay his note given last Saturday, till Monday Morning. And he sat with me talking full two hours— While Peter stuck to his last, he was an industrious, spirited, promising young man. But the Demon of speculation fastened his fangs upon him, and he is on the high road to ruin, or rather already there— I have a Letter from Ellis Gray Loring with a pamphlet on the case of the African Captives— I began a reply to the Letter, but think of the whole subject only with mortification.
17. IV:30. Sunday
Sun rose 6:53. Set 4:37. Day 9 hours 44 minutes.

My wife passed the night in watching with the child till 4 this morning, when she came to bed, leaving her with her mother and Mrs Kirke—composed, painless, but speechless as she had been the whole Night.— I immediately rose and repaired to my chamber where in a cloudless sky the Morning Star and Arcturus looked in upon me without cheering my Soul, too much oppressed with sorrow and fear to take pleasure in the beauties— I went and saw the Sun rise from the S.E. corner of Charles’s house— He rose over the stone temple, and in rising passed behind the open steeple so as to be partially eclipsed by its cupola.— Mr Ellis, a young candidate for the Ministry preached this morning from that remarkable text Jeremiah 10.23. [“]O Lord, I know that the way of man is not in himself; it is not in man that walketh to direct his steps.” The object of the Discourse was to shew the error of a common adage that man is the creature of circumstances, and it proved that it ought not to be so—that it is not always so. That principle should always, and sometimes does rise above all circumstances of which he gave examples in Zwingle, Melancthon and Luther—and Jerome of Prague and Cranmer for examples of a noble recovery to truth and Martyrdom, after the weakness of apostasy upon compulsion— Mr Ellis endeavoured also to rescue his text from the construction which would give encouragement to the doctrine of fatalism, and said the problem of conciliation and free will never had been, and never would be solved. The condition of my family deprived me of the pleasure of inviting Mr Ellis to dine with us.— When I came home from the morning service the Doctors Holbrook and Woodward had been here— They said the child was not worse, but they gave no hope, and she has not recovered the power of speech— Louisa C. Smith was gone— Thomas took her in the Carriage to Mr James H. Foster’s at Boston, where she will find another afflicted family. She is herself slowly recovering from an illness which has confined her six weeks to her chamber— Mr Ellis’s afternoon Sermon was from Matthew 19.14. “But Jesus said, Suffer little children; and forbid them not, to come unto me; for of such is the kingdom of Heaven.”— A text, at this moment especially to me yet more admonitory and consolatory than that of the morning. Mr Ellis described the condition of childhood as a state of Peace, of Faith, of Hope, of Innocence, perhaps a little beyond the life— And he said that was the condition in which the Christian candidate for the kingdom of Heaven must place himself, before he could obtain admittance to it— But Oh! blessed God! we must resign this child— We must suffer her to go unto Jesus—and not forbid— Receive her to thy kingdom in Heaven; and be thou the God of her widowed mother to sustain her in this sore trial and affliction— Mr E. Price Greenleaf who walked with me over the hill in returning from the afternoon meeting kindly offered any personal service which it may be in his power to render us in our affliction. I read the 4th. and 5th. Sermons of Barrow upon Industry, which I should estimate higher, if I could read them with the application of an unoccupied, and unagitated mind— There is in these discourses a moss of accumulated thought; but the style is dry, seasoned chiefly with greek and Latin Quotations—crusty like Swift without his salt— In the discourse upon Industry of Gentlemen he recommends to them the examples of the Gentlemen Abraham, Isaac Jacob—Moses, David, Solomon &c— I wrote to Minott Thayer and E. G Loring.
18. V. Monday.

Our dear child is drawing slowly but surely to her end. She continues speechless, but not insensible— May the mercy of God be extended to her mother grand mother and to me;—who have had yesterday last night and this day distinct warnings to set my house in order, in preparation for the same event to myself— The Doctors Holbrook and Woodward were here in consultation at 11. this morning, and prescribed, but had no cheering hope to give, other than that life might yet linger with her a few days— I told Dr Holbrook that yesterday morning on rising from bed, I had staggered as if but half awake— That I had felt top-heavy without pain or sickness the whole day— That I had taken a Seidlitz powder this morning, but had yet some swimming in the brain— He said the Seidlitz powder was not drastic enough, and advised a warm foot-bath, and calomel or Castor Oil— I did not tell the Doctor of my diseased morning dream, and to avoid giving more trouble to the family or alarm to my wife postponed his remedies. Mr Eleazar Beal of Randolph was here, to enquire if I could give him any information of the history or statistics of that town, of which he is now occupied in making a survey. I could tell him nothing about it, except that my uncle Elihu had made a settlement there in the woods, about 75 years ago, and that a grandson of his named John was I believed now living there, about 30 years of age— He said he knew him well—that he was a director in the Bank and had lately built a handsome house. Mr Beal promised me a copy of his Survey when it is published— I took my Letters to Fisher A. Kingsbury and Minott Thayer to the Post-Office, and a Letter to Elizabeth C. Adams, from her brother Isaac Hull— I found Mrs Stebbins and her at dinner. Her mother was confined to her chamber with cramps in the stomach; and she herself is forbidden to go out from the house in this November weather— Mr G. W. Beale brought me this afternoon, the Resolutions of the Towns of Randolph and Quincy, respecting the centennial celebration of the incorporation of Braintree— The Randolph Resolutions, agree to join in the celebration— That I should deliver the Oration, and appoint a Committee of Arrangements for time and place— They were passed on the 11th. The Quincy Resolutions postpone to the 10th. of September 1840. provided the celebration shall be in this Town and I will deliver the Oration— They were passed on the 15th. Mr Beale said that Mr Minott Thayer Chairman of the Braintree Committee had not attended the joint Committee, but that Braintree insisted upon having it there; though they meant the Oration should be delivered at Mr Perkins’s church in Weymouth— I said I should wait to hear further from Braintree— Lewis Bass was here. He and Harvey Field are Joint-tenants of my Penn’s— Field is not punctual in his payment, and my son wrote to Bass to urge or supply the payment— He said Field had promised to pay this week, and if he did not—he must. He asked me about my tax bill, and I told him he might take Field’s debt in part payment of it— Mr William Ellis of Dedham, and Peter Turner were successively here this Evening—and each of them spent an hour or more with me.
19. IV:30. Tuesday.

Mr William Ellis reminded me last evening that it was the 84th. anniversary of the great earthquake— I had never charged my memory with the date but I remembered that it was the earliest entry on my fathers diary minutes— He began with them at Worcester 1. Jany 1756. on a small sheet of foolscap paper folded into 16. pages. The year begins on the right hand page of the 2d. leaf but at the top of the left hand page is an entry apparently made at Worcester of the Earthquake which on the 18th of November 1755—had awaked him from sleep, and for the space of 4 minutes made the house shake and crack as if it was coming to pieces— He says—I was then at my fathers house—and adds that it shook down seven chimnies in the town of Braintree— It probably suggested to him the idea of minuting events in the form of a Journal; which floated in his mind till the beginning of the next year.— I looked up this manuscript and read to Mr Ellis the entry about the earthquake— The 18th of November is also one of the memorable days of my own life; being the single day and night in 1806. which I passed at the House of Mr Gulliver in Poplar Street, Boston. Mr Ellis talked much about sundry claims for pensions in his neighbourhood, and said he should write to me concerning one of them— Peter Turner, paid me the 55 dollars he had borrowed last Saturday week, and took up his note. He talked much and asked me to repeat for the fourth time a good saying which had struck him, which upon attempting to repeat to his wife had slip’d from his memory. I told him that it was the common adage that enough is always a little more than a man has got— That’s it, said he—why did not I remember it— But I did remember the saying of John Jacob Astor, that riches are nothing and that a man, with five hundred thousand dollars clear of the world is as well off as a rich man. My Son and his wife came out from Boston this morning— He returned home after dinner— She remains for the night— The Doctors Holbrook and Woodward met here at 4 this afternoon, and thought the child could not survive the Night; and gave this opinion to the family, except the mother who discovered from the condition of the child the hopelessness of the case; and was so overwhelmed with grief and it became necessary to remove her to another chamber— Miss Cutts accompanied her— My wife and Charles’s retained all their self-possession and watch the dear child with Mrs Kirke without intermission— Mr Lunt called this Evening; and at my request in my chamber prayed for the child and for us all— I did not take him in to the sick chamber, dreading the effect of such a service on the agonizing mother but his prayer was earnest and appropriate, and soothing to my own feelings— From 9 to 10 O’Clock this evening I forced myself to pass an hour by the bedside of this suffering Seraph as she seemed to me to be— Her sufferings were not acute, but in her beseeching and moaning helplessness they wrung my soul— Nether my wife nor Abby would leave the bedside— I retired without undressing for the Night.
20. IV:30. Wednesday.
Sun rose 6:57. Set 4:35. Day 9 hours 38 minutes

From the S.E. corner of Charles’s House, showing his first beam outside the Eastern edge of the Stone temple’s steeple, crossing the open part of the steeple as he rose and when full risen showing his western limb on the western side.
Fahrenheit at Sun rise 26. A clear cold day.

It has pleased Almighty God, in the wise and good dispensations of his Providence, this day to dispose of my Granddaughter Georgiana Frances Adams, daughter of my dear deceased Son John, and of his wife, Mary Catherine Hellen.— The child died at ten minutes before six O’Clock this afternoon, in the same chamber and bed in which on the 10th. of September 1830 she was born— At the hour of her birth I addressed a prayer to God for her worldly and eternal welfare— That she might be blessed with a long life of prosperity usefulness and virtue. That prayer has not been all denied— She has been upwards of nine years one of the chief delight of the lives of both her Grandparents—of her father while he lived, and of her widowed and now disconsolate mother— I had engaged to deliver the second Lecture on the Smithsonian bequest this Evening at the Quincy Lyceum. Last evening, I gave the Lecture to Mr Lunt requesting him in the event of my not being there to deliver it in my place—which he readily promised— This morning, the child seemed likely to continue several days longer. I called on Mr Lunt and as the Lyceum was adjourned to half past 6. I desired him to take the lecture with him, and wait till 7— If the child should be so that I could attend, I would come and deliver the Lecture myself. But if I should not be there at 7. I wished him to read it. Mr Beale was with Mr Lunt, about the centennial celebration of the incorporation of Braintree— When I came home I found the Doctors Holbrook and Bigelow here—the child not having yet exhibited symptoms of speedy dissolution— We dined, and about 3. O’Clock I went into the sick chamber and found my wife Miss Cutts and Mrs Kirke, kneeling at the bed side; and the child in the agonies of death. They were terrible, but I can speak of them only in general terms— For two long hours and more I witnessed this struggle of pure and spotless infancy with the king of terrors— Doctor Bigelow who had foreseen what was coming had given me repeated and most emphatic assurances that whatever convulsive appearances there might be there would be no suffering of pain; that all consciousness was departed, and all sensibility extinct— But when I saw and heard, I could not believe him such tortur’d spasms, such shrieking groans Oh! was it possible they should be without feeling. Oh! my God! I could only fall upon my knees, and uniting my voice with that of my wife implore thy mercy upon the expiring angel and upon us.— At a quarter past five the heaviest agony was over—the breathing was short and quick the moaning low and indistinct— I went into the other to endeavour to sooth and compose the mother scarcely less agonized than the child— At ten minutes before six Miss Cutts came in. The mother exclaimed she’s gone! Miss Cutts hung her head in silence, and the Mother burst into a flood of tears.—
21. IV:30 Thursday.

When Miss Cutts last evening came in to Mary’s chamber the silent Messenger of the fatal tidings, I left her with Mary, and returned to the Bedchamber where I found my dear wife, Mrs Kirke, Mary the Irish-woman, and Mrs Goods, sobbing in the deepest affliction, and the child lying in perfect composure in the sleep of death, with a countenance serene as if in heaven, and a cheek yet warm to my last agonizing kiss— Mrs Goods her Nurse had at the desire of her mother, been sent for to come from Washington, and had arrived after I had left the chamber, just to see her expire.— My wife recovering all her fortitude went to soothe and speak words of comfort to the unhappy mother— The men of the household, Kirke, Jeremy, Thomas came to take a last look at the universal darling, and I retired for the remainder of the evening to my chamber in a state approaching to stupefaction. At Sunrise this morning I called on Mr Lunt, and found that he had delivered last Evening at the Quincy Lyceum, my second Lecture on the Smithsonian bequest— He said they had waited for me till 7. O’Clock, and Mr. French the Schoolmaster said he had been at my house about six O’Clock, and had been told that the child was dead— Mr Lunt was going into Boston this morning and I asked him if he would deliver that same Lecture, and the special address to the members of the Mechanic Apprentice’s Library Association for me and in my name at the Masonic Temple this Evening.— He promised he would, and on his way to Boston called at my house, when I gave him a Letter to George L. Curry, President of the Association, stating my inability to deliver the Lecture and address in person, and that Mr Lunt has consented to deliver them for me and in my name— Mr Beale called this morning and offered his services for any of the funeral arrangements— Minott Thayer was here, and left with me the Braintree Town Resolutions of the 12th. instt. relating to the centennial celebration— They agree to invite me to deliver the Oration, and to postpone the celebration till the 10th of September, but insist upon having it in Braintree— Mr Thayer seemed to think that Braintree and Randolph might have the celebration without the participation of Quincy; but I told him that I could not participate— That if there was any disagreement, I could take no part in it— I was at the service of the three towns if they could agree; but for any partial celebration they must look out for another speaker. He said some were desirous of having President Josiah Quincy, and I said I thought they could not select a better— Mr Thayer said he would report to the Town-meeting at Braintree precisely what I had said— Josiah Adams junr. came early this morning and took the measure for a coffin which he said he would have ready by 11. O’Clock to-morrow morning— My Son came out from Boston before dinner and returned home toward Evening. We concluded to have the funeral at half past two O’Clock P.M. on Saturday— Alpheus Spear was here about the Parish tax on the Mount Wollaston farm and said he would call again next Tuesday Morning— There was a flight of Snow this forenoon, with a cold clearing off and bright Sunset—
22. V. Friday.
Fahrenheit after Sun rise 20.

Mrs Kirke was sent to Boston with the Carriage, and brought out my granddaughter Mary Louisa, who went in with her aunt when she removed to the city, and has remained with her during the sickness of her Sister. She slept last Night in the chamber with us; but my dear wife had a sleepless Night, was very unwell all this day and went to bed early this evening sick— The night was intensely cold, the day bright and beautiful but frosty, and weaker than the child we are about to lay in the tomb, manly Fortitude reproaches me with forebodings of other sorrows to aggravate those which bow me to the earth— Let me rather record our blessings— Our neighbours are kind and sympathise with our afflictions. Mr William Appleton was here and offered every service, in his power— Mr Lunt called and returned me the second Lecture on the Smithsonian bequest, with the Address to the members of the Mechanic Apprentices Library Association; which he delivered last Evening for me at the Masonic Temple in Boston, and which he said was well received— My Son came out from Boston, dined with us, and returned after dinner— I sent by him to Mr George Alexander Otis, the three volumes he had lent me of Prescott’s History of Ferdinand and Isabella— His own Manuscript translation of Cicero upon Old Age, sundry Letters which he left with me concerning his translation of the Tusculans, and with all these a Letter to himself, in which I have been desirous of doing him full justice without flattering him— The undertaking in this Country to publish a translation of Cicero, deserves every encouragement that can be fairly given to it— And this undertaking is the more meritorious in a man who never enjoyed the benefit of a collegiate education— I wrote also and sent by my Son an answer to Professor Walter Channing, declining an invitation received from him as Chairman of the Executive Committee of the Franklin Course of Lectures to deliver again the first Smithsonian Lecture at the Masonic Temple next Monday Evening. Josiah Adams junr. was here before dinner and I saw the remains of that beautiful and darling child deposited in their last earthly mansion— Ruth Turner and Mary Ann French were here the whole day and evening in mantua-making work— Elizabeth C. Adams also spent the day here but went home early in the Evening to her mother’s— She has been since her return from Miss Miller’s wedding confined to her bed and chamber with a severe cold and cough till this day. Her mothers recovery from the painful and critical operation of taking out a cancer from the breast, though fair in promise at the first has become tardy and lingering, and she is becoming discouraged— I went this Evening into Mr Beale’s— There was some question about bearers. F. Augustus Whitney—C. P. Cranch and Dr Stetson being unable to attend— George Beale said he would write and request Charles Miller to come out from Boston. I passed the remainder of the Evening in solitary affliction.
23. IV:15. Saturday
Fahrenheit 14. at Sunrise.

Ruth Turner and Mary Ann French were here all the morning at work. Ann Beale part of the Morning. Josiah Adams junr. came before noon, and soon after my Son came out from Boston, with his wife, his daughter Louisa Catherine and his Son John Quincy— At half past 2 O’Clock the Revd. Mr Wolcott Minister of the Episcopal Church read the funeral service, and was followed by Mr Lunt with a most affecting and fervent prayer. We then went in procession to the grave-yard— The bearers of the pall were Mr Beale’s son George; Mr William Appleton’s son, Richard Cranch Greenleaf, and Charles Miller— I walked immediately after the hearse with my Son, and his Son John Quincy— A few Neighbours followed on foot, and three or four Carriages— My dear wife notwithstanding her own illness in one of them— The coffin was deposited in the family vault immediately over that of her father, and about four in the afternoon I thanked the Gentlemen who had severally given their aid and attendance at the last act of service to the dear departed child—and returned home— Her mother could not go in the procession; but was present at the performance of the service, and much affected by the prayer of Mr Lunt— My wife for whom the trial of the procession was too severe, fainted on her return, and immediately retired to a sick bed— Mrs John Greenleaf, Mrs Stebbins, Elizabeth C. Adams and Mary Harrod went home— Charles with his wife and two children returned to Boston— Miss Cutts with the surviving daughter of the bereaved mother gave the evening in soothing attendance to her, and I was left alone, to bless the God of the sorrowful, for the numberless mercies that I have received at his hands, to remember with grateful heart all those with which I am yet indulged; to implore a continuance of them to my dearest partner and friend, and to all around me for whom I am bound to pray and to prepare me as well for all the manifestations of his will yet reserved for me upon earth, as for my own great and last change. I endeavoured to subdue my Spirit to the temper of resignation— I sought employment to occupy the mind. Having many unanswered Letters upon my files, I took up and answered briefly one from Mr Benjamin D. Silliman of Brooklyn, Long Island— I have also received a Letter from Rufus A. Johnson, Editor of the Christian Register, a religious Newspaper, printed at Boston, asking my permission to publish my first Smithsonian Lecture in parts in that paper—but the publication of the first Lecture without the second would be premature— Charles took with him to Boston the four volumes lent me by Ellis Gray Loring to return them.
24. IV:30. Sunday.

Immediately after breakfast, I called upon Mr Lunt at his house, and requested him to read the following note at the morning service. John Quincy Adams with his wife and family desire prayers that the death of his granddaughter may be sanctified to them— I asked him for a copy of his prayer yesterday at the funeral of the dear child, which deeply affected her mother. She expressed to me the wish for a copy of it, and Mr Lunt said he had not but would write it out and give us a copy of it— My dear wife was confined the whole day to her bed. Charles came out from Boston—attended the morning and afternoon service, and then returned to Boston, taking with him Miss Cutts, who wishes before her return to Washington to make another short visit to Elizabeth Crowninshield. Mr Lunt performed the morning service at Meeting and preached from Ezekiel 2.9. [“]And when I looked, behold an hand was sent unto me: and lo, a roll of a book was therein— 3.1. Moreover he said unto me, Son of man, eat that thou findest, eat this roll, and go speak unto the house of Israel. 2. So I opened my Mouth, and he caused me to eat that roll”— Mr Lunt remarked upon the modes of figurative language customary in diffent ages of the world; and explained the purport of the injunction upon the prophet to imbibe the principles of the roll, so as to make them a part of his own substance— He read my note, and prayed fervently as it requested— Mr Whitney preached the afternoon Sermon from Psalm 18:30. “As for God his way is perfect.” a kind and affectionate discourse of soothing consolation and of pious exhortation, equally friendly, and appropriate to the occasion; without direct allusion to our heavy calamity— The closing hymn of the service was the 215th. the last four verses.

lg.l: Let faith suppress each rising fear,
My Makers will, has plac’d me here
He, to my every trial knows
Then why thus heavy, O my Soul?
Thy thoughts with vain impatience roll,
Though griefs unnumber’d throng thee round,
Whose finger marks the Seas their bound,

div.p: Mr Lunt read the Proclamation for the annual Thanksgiving next Thursday; and gave notice that the communion would be administered next Sunday, and the yearly collection taken up— Elizabeth C. Adams came and spent the day here, and is to stay till Miss Cutts returns— Mr Lunt lent me the Christian Register of yesterday—containing a notice of my first Smithsonian Lecture delivered at the Masonic Temple on the 14th. with a personal panegyric for which I ought to humble myself before God, with confusion of face— I wrote two short Letters, and read two Sermons of Barrow, upon the Folly of Slander, and part of one against Detraction— There is one against rash censuring and judging.
25. IV:15. Monday

As we were returning from Meeting yesterday morning there was a light sprinkling of rain with the wind at Southeast and a warm atmosphere— It continued and increased all the remainder of the day, came to a heavy gale of wind before Night— Tempestuous the whole Night and all this day till about half an hour before Sunset when the dark curtain rose from the Western Horizon— The rainbow formed its brilliant Arch over the Eastern waters, and the Sun went down serene and calm, as if to cheer us even in his departure— Charles did not come out from Boston. My wife was barely able to leave her bed; and under a depression which divine mercy alone can relieve I began making preparations for my departure for Washington— As the sky was clearing off, Deacon Spear came in with an account of the sale last Thursday of the wood standing in the grove at the foot of Penn’s hill; amounting to 1232 dollars and 50 cents yet to be collected, and greatly needed— The Banks of New-York and Boston persevere in the ostensible payment of specie relying only upon the forbearance of their creditors to demand it, and forbearing to press upon their debtors— But as they decline almost all discounts, debtors to others plead for time, till the banks shall discount, and the suspension of payments, and of the collection of debts is almost universal— Shortly after Sunset I walked over the hill to Mr Lunts and returned to him the Christian Register which he had lent me. He gave me a copy of the prayer which he made at the funeral on Saturday, and I gave it to Mary who had requested it— He gave me also a Letter from his father Henry Lunt to him concerning a claim to prize money in behalf of his father Henry Lunt who was a Lieutenant in the Bonhomme Richard under the command of John Paul Jones, in the cruize when she took the Serapis—with the Letter there is a declaration of Henry Lunt the younger; and a deposition, of Moses Davenport of Newbury Port declaratory of the fact that Henry Lunt the elder was a Lieutenant in the Bonhomme Richard. These papers I am to remember at Washington— After I returned home Josiah Adams junr. came and sat an hour of the Evening with me— He had borrowed, my first Lecture on the Smithsonian bequest expressing a wish to take a copy of my report of January 1836.— He now returned me the manuscript, and shewed me a copy of the whole Lecture, made as he assured me, by his daughter Sarah Adams 13 years of age and a scholar of Jonathan French—written in a very good hand— Mr French worked in my garden in the year 1837. And Mr Adams told me how he came to be the favourite schoolmaster of the town— I have written Letters to Mrs. Catherine W. Callender at Boston, concerning a pension claim—to I. K. Tefft corresponding Secretary of the Georgia Historical Society, in answer to one from him announcing that they had elected me one of their honorary members, and to William A Russell at New-Haven, declining to deliver the Φ.B.K. Address.
26. IV:30. Tuesday.
Sun rose 7:4. Set 4:30. Day 9 hours 26 minutes.
Fahrenheit at Sunrise 14.— Boston—

I saw the Sunrise from the S.E. corner of Charless house about the width of a disk South of the Steeple of the Stone temple— The air was biting cold— After breakfast I went to the Bank with a check for 200 dollars to defray the expenses of our journey to Washington and then went immediately into Boston— Just before reaching the free-bridge I met Charles and his wife going out to Quincy— I went to the livery stable in Hawley Place where we put up our horses and carriage— My first care was to provide myself with wintry garments—a wrapper cloak 23. Velvet waitcoat 5. Kerseymere Pantaloons 6. and 4 pair of worsted stockings 5. Then I called at Mr Crowninshields, where I found Miss Cutts, and promised to call for her at one— At Charles’s house I saw his three boys with Henry’s Nurse Catherine. At Dr George Parkman’s; he was not at home, and Mrs Parkman was engaged. He overtook me however, and brought to me at the stable, two sheets of the Boston Medical and Surgical Journal, N. 14 and 16 of Volume 21. At Dr Frothingham’s I saw Charles’s daughter Louisa Catherine— Mrs Frothingham was not at home. Governor Everett was also gone out, but I saw and took leave of Mrs Everett— Just after the bell had rung, I went from the stable in Hawley place to Mr Crowninshield’s where I took up Miss Cutts, and we came out to Quincy to dine— Charles and his wife left us soon after dinner and returned to Boston; after he had taken up for me a note for 300 dollars at the Bank, for our journey— Captain John Hardwick was here with Mrs Lake, widow of a man who went last year to build a wharf of Quincy Granite at Maracaybo, in central America— He accomplished the work, but took sick and died last Jane— The consul named Dubbs was a contractor with Lake by the agency of Lombard and Whittemore at Boston. Mrs Lake complains that the Consul has sent home only a part of her husband’s effects, and particularly neither his account books nor her Letters to him. I advised her to make a written statement of the facts, with a declaration of Lombard and Whittemore, and to address the Secretary of State, to require further account from the Consul Dubbs— To send the papers by mail to Washington, and I promised to deliver them in person to the Secretary of State— I told Captain Hardwick that the Collector George Bancroft’s Letter to Mr Rice should be presented with the petition it would ensure its rejection— He asked me then to withhold the Petition till Rice shall have time to apply to Mr Bancroft again— I thought it strange that Bancroft should give this man, to support his Petition a Letter which he must have known would certainly prove fatal to it— Alpheus Spear came and paid me 38:50 for the parish tax of 1839. on the Mount Wollaston farm— He says he sends on the average 45 gallons of Milk every Morning to Boston— Mr Lunt called this Evening and took leave.
27. IV:30. Wednesday.
Boston— Stonington. Steamer Narragansett.

The morning till noon was absorbed in preparations for departure— Elizabeth C. Adams came to bid us a kind farewell. My son came out from Boston, with supplies to save me the mortification of having to borrow a five dollar bill to enable me to reach Washington with my family as happened in 1836— We took an early dinner, and leaving the house in charge of Mr and Mrs Kirk at half past one P.M departed from Quincy, in Gillett’s omnibus—in company named in the margin.

The vacant space can only be filled in Heaven— Departure from home for long distances of time and space is always a bitter draught for me— This time it was the wormwood and the gall— The memory of the past weeks, and the prospect of the coming months were clouded with sorrow and gloom. There were many anxieties in the journey itself before me, and forebodings of nothing good to follow— The conscious Sentiment of my own utter helplessness, oppresses me by day and haunts me by Night, for which my only resource is to frequent and fervent and importunate prayer to the being who has hither to preserved my life, and crowned it with unnumbered blessings; forever blessed be his name!— My Son left his horse and chaise in charge of Kirk, and accompanied us into Boston— We came to the Rail-way depot a quarter before 3. a full hour too soon. At 3. a train of Cars started for Providence with Passengers who were to take the Steamer Narragansett there and go round Point Judith.— There was yet an hour of waiting during which, I walked to Mr James H. Foster’s and took leave of Louisa C.
