Smith, who appeared to be and said she was quite recovered in health— Of the rest of the family I saw only Louisa Foster.— On returning to the Cars I found Mr Abbott Lawrence, and Mr Leverett Saltonstall members of H.R.U.S. from Boston and Salem were going with us.— P. P. F. Degrand and Dr George Parkman, were there to bid us farewell; and Charles’s two elder Sons John Quincy and Charles Francis, who with their father saw us off.— At 4 we started, and as we whirled along by the blue hills a beautiful Sunset in the opposite direction, after a cloudy day, and followed by a deepening crimson twilight, cheered me as with an auspicious omen, which I hailed with grateful joy.— We reached Stonington about 9. P.M and embarked in the Steamer Narragansett— But my wife was quite unwell and Mrs. John Adams very ill.
28. IV:30. Thursday
Long-Island Sound— New-York. Philadelphia

After we embarked last Evening in the Steamer Narragansett at Stonington, she was detained about an hour at the wharf, taking in freight, and waiting for a tide— Going out of the harbour, the boat grounded which detained us some time longer— The night was blustering, and the wind directly ahead. The Cabin was over-heated and I slept not a wink— After lying in wait three or four hours for a doze, I abridged the remnant of time till half past 4. by ruminating an autograph for Mr Serruys— I had after rising, two hours of waiting for daylight, but the boat had got into smooth water.— Between 9 and 10 in the morning, we landed at New-York, and went to the City Hotel— Mrs John Adams was quite recovered, but my wife was suffering with a severe sick head ache— At 7 O’Clock this morning the boat for Amboy had gone, and that line for Philadelphia runs only once a day. At 9 the morning Cars on the Trenton railroad had departed, and our alternative was to go in the afternoon train or remain in New-York till to-morrow Morning— My business required that I should be at Philadelphia in the early part of the day to-morrow. I advised my wife to remain with part of the family till the morning and let me proceed with the remainder this afternoon— After some hesitation she concluded to go on, all together— Before dinner I walked round some of the Streets, first alone and then with Miss Cutts— We viewed the new Marble Custom-house, and the new Quincy granite Exchange in front of which in the middle of the Street were lying three of the 32 feet long pillars, which we had seen drawn by 70 oxen and 10 horses past our house at Quincy.— They are not yet raised to their position in the building. We passed round the whole quarter, where the conflagration of 1835. 17. December had swept away twenty millions of dollars worth of property— It is all built over again in more costly style than it was before; but the shops and Stores were all closed, it being Thanksgiving day here as well as in Massachusetts.— We passed through the battery where were gangs of boys taking their pastime at Cricket—returning to the Hotel, we met Mr and Mrs Charles A. Davis, and Mr and Mrs Sidney Brooks, who were going to visit our Ladies, but upon hearing of their indisposition sent their compliments instead— They gave us at the City Hotel, an exquisite dinner, in Thanksgiving profusion, and with assiduous, and unremitted attendance— At a quarter before 5 we crossed the ferry to Jersey City, and in addition to our former companions Lawrence and Saltonstall, we now met Aaron Vanderpoel and James Monroe members elect of H.R.U.S. from the State and City of New-York— We had another beautiful Sunset twilight and evening, but a continuous ride of near 7 hours without leaving my seat, except to change Cars at the Trenton Bridge was tedious enough— About half past 11. we came to the depot in Market Street— There we went in an Omnibus, to the Washington House kept by Captain Jeffries in Chesnut Street— As we entered the Lady’s parlour the City Clock struck twelve— My wife was so much overcome with fatigue and a sick head ache that she with difficulty reached a bed chamber in the third Story and went immediately to bed—
29. VII. Friday—

We despatched at 8 O’Clock this morning three of our company by the railway cars to Baltimore— Mrs Goods, Mary Wentworth and Jeremy Leary; but my wife was so ill, that she kept her bed nearly the whole day— Mrs John Adams was averse to leaving her chamber in her affliction, and declined even calling upon her friend Mrs Stockton— I went out before breakfast, and at the N.E. corner of Chesnut and 7th. Streets 5 doors from our inn, at Jones and Hutchinson’s druggist’s shop, procured a double dose of Rochelle Salt’s and a Viol of Essence of Peppermint, for the patient—a small viol of volatile salts which I gave as a keepsake to Mary Cutts as a keepsake, and a Tooth brush for myself, At breakfast and dinner at the private ordinary we met Mrs Tudor and Mrs. Stewart on their return from New-York to Washington— They had been to New-York to meet Mrs Gardiner, who embarked there for the Island of Santa Cruce, with her daughter feared to be in a consumption— I received shortly before dinner a Letter from Mrs Tudor,requesting me to write to Commodore Stuart, and advise him to sign a relinquishment of his claim in the right of his wife to a portion of the money granted by the act of Congress or the last Session to the legal representatives of William Tudor jr. a request with which it was impossible for me to comply— And at the dinner table Mrs Tudor came to me and said she wished me to take no further notice of her Letter; Commodore Stuart being not now in the City— I went with Miss Cutts, and my granddaughter Mary Louisa, to view the exhibition of upwards of one thousand Chinese figures, paintings and other Articles at the Hall of the Philadelphia Museum in 9th. Street.— They are in 53 cases, with others suspended round the spacious and new built Philadelphia Hall— I was soon obliged to leave my companions, and go to the exchange brokers E. W. Clark and Co. upon whom Charles had given me an order from Gilbert and Dean at Boston for 150 dollars in bankable money—for which I received in gold 135 dollars with 14 cents allowing a discount of 11 per cent— Charles had taken it at a discount of 10 per cent. I went also to the Office of George Rundle Treasurer of the Schuylkill permanent bridge and received from him a check on the Bank of Pennsylvania for 342 dollars, being for dividends on the stock till at the last winter Session of the Pennsylvania Legislature, the Charter was annulled and the bridge made free— Of the sum that I received 204 dollars was for 34 per cent of the Capital repaid; and Mr. Rundle said about 40 per cent more might ultimately be paid to the Stockholders.— At the Bank of Pennsylvania I took an order for the money on the bank of the Metropolis at Washington— I called at Mr John Sergeants house, where they told me that he and Mrs Sergeant had gone yesterday to Washington. I met in the Street Mrs N. Biddle who told me that her husband went yesterday to Andalusia; but would return this afternoon— I returned to the Chinese exhibition, but Miss Cutts and Mary-Louisa were gone— After dinner, Mr N. Biddle called upon me, and I went with him and spent the Evening at judge Hopkinson’s.
30. VI. Saturday.
From Philadelphia to Baltimore and Washington.

My wife had so far recovered from her illness that she was able to proceed to the completion of our Journey— The Steam boat lines by the way of Newcastle and Frenchtown have ceased, and the only travel from Philadelphia to Baltimore now, is by the Railway— At 8 O’Clock this morning we departed from the depot N. 368. Market Street in the Cars, with horses for about 4 miles—then exchanged for the locomotive— Mr Abbott Lawrence was again of our party, and Governor Lincoln in the place of Mr Saltonstall who had gone on yesterday. This Railway is very tedious, and a miserable exchange for the alternate steam boats and cars down the Delaware river and Chesapeake Bay. The country on the road is very uninteresting; particularly, at this Season of the year— Our progress was this day unusually slow, and it was 3 in the afternoon when we reached the depot at Baltimore— There is a Hotel there opened on the opposite side of the Street, where we found a dinner on the table, spread to receive us.— After dinner, a Mr Symington, a Scotchman settled in the Island of Madeira, and travelling in this country for custom, asked the Landlord to introduce him to me, and told me that he had been about two months in this Country, and proposed to go shortly to Washington to hear the debates in Congress— And he gave me his card— The Mayor of Baltimore, with General Leakin, Mr Barnum and two other gentlemen came in to give me a greeting— I understood they were a deputation from the City Council, or some other body of whigs to pay this compliment to Mr Henry Clay; and after performing that service, they volunteered the same to me, which I suppose they thought they could hardly help; but in which I take no delight. I found Mr Clay in the same Car, with my family, and Mr Crittenden his Colleague Senator from Kentucky. Mr John Pope was in another Car of the same train— There was a crowd of idle gazers round the Car, to look at Mr Clay, and they delayed the departure of the train nearly half an hour after their appointed time which was 4. O’Clock— The passage to Washington was thus nearly all benighted; but we reached the depot at the foot of the Capitol hill about half past six in the Evening.— Miss Cutts’s brother was there to meet her, and Walter Hellen to meet his Sister— Thomas engaged a Carriage for the Ladies, and I left him in charge of the baggage to see it safely home— I walked up to the Capitol, and went into the Hall of the House of Representatives, where I found all the seats but ten or twelve of the worst in the house taken— I wrote my name on one of those that were left, and then walked home to my house in F. Street— At 7. in the Evening I found safely housed there, except Miss Cutts who had alighted at her father’s house— Mrs W. S. Smith was there, as I had left her last April— Her husband still in prison.
Day— Thus ends the month— I commence on the Winter establishment to-morrow.
